A communication transmitted from Louis A. DePasquale, City Manager, relative to the biennial City
of Cambridge Resident Telephone Survey for 2020.

I. Communications and Reports from Other City Officers
1.

A communication was received from City Manager, Louie DePasquale, transmitting a presentation
for the Roundtable/Working Group City Council Meeting schedule for January 25, 2021.

City of Cambridge

Page 1

1

CMA 2021 #2
IN CITY COUNCIL
January 25, 2021
I am transmitting the results of the biennial City of Cambridge Resident Telephone Survey for
2020. I am very pleased to report that overall opinions of the City's core attributes remain very
favorable, and residents' opinions of the City's COVID-19 response are widely regarded as
positive.
On perhaps the most all-encompassing measure of resident sentiment, satisfaction with overall
experiences with the City is at a record high level for the 20-year history of this survey program.
Last year was an incredibly challenging year, and I am extremely proud that during a pandemic,
the percentage of respondents who are "totally" satisfied with their interactions with the City
remained at the highest level we have seen over the course of this survey program. Moreover, the
combined overall satisfaction rose from 55% in 2018 to 60% today. I believe this reflects our
highly capable and extremely dedicated workforce and the focus they place on the initiatives and
priorities of the Council. I want to thank City staff for their commitment to our community and
for their hard work.
This year's survey asked a series of questions regarding the COVID-19 pandemic. Overall, 81%
of respondents rated the City's handling of the pandemic as "excellent" or "good." Specific to the
City's performance during the COVID-19 pandemic, 79% of respondents rated public
information services as "excellent" or "good," 75% rated public health services as "excellent" or
"good," and 73% of respondents rated the City's online/virtual services as "excellent" or "good."
When asked about COVID-19 testing services, 56% of respondents provided a rating of
"excellent" or "good," while 19% “did not know.” Almost three-quarters of survey respondents
indicated that they closely follow public health updates and recommendations on COVID-19.
Finally, survey respondents indicated they trust the state government the most for public health
information (38%), followed by the City and state equally (26%), followed by the City
government alone (24%), and lastly, the federal government (4%). Almost a third of respondents
indicated that they experienced a loss of employment income since mid-March, with job loss
twice as high as the norm (64%) among Hispanic residents and significantly higher among
African-American residents (45%).
The survey serves as a valuable tool to help inform us about issues and areas where the City is
excelling and areas that the City may need to pay particular attention to, and where we might
focus even more efforts in the future. I am proud that areas related to City performance, access

Packet Pg. 2

1

to services, and public information have seen increases.
Overall city performance is up since 2018, with fully two-thirds (66%) of respondents giving the
City either "excellent" or "good" rating. The City's public information received an "excellent" or
"good" rating from 83% of respondents. And this year, the fewest residents since the inception
of the survey agreed with a statement that they were unable to conduct business with the City
during regular business hours. In 2018, 43% agreed with the statement, and in 2020 just 32%
agreed.
Among the 11 City services we explored for performance, excellent ratings improved on: 'street
maintenance' (+9) and 'public information' (+3). Several services experienced drops in
"excellent" ratings from 2018. The largest declines were: fire department services (-16), schools
and education (-15), and police department services (-10).
Affordable housing/housing (30%) was again identified as the "single most important issue
facing the City of Cambridge today." Housing affordability continues to be a significant regional
concern, and these results reaffirm the City's strong financial and policy commitment and
prioritization of the issue. The COVID-19 pandemic (17%), educations and schools (9%), jobs
and economy (7%), and climate change issues (5%) round out the top five "single most
important" issues identified in the 2020 survey.
Residents' ratings of the quality of life in Cambridge have risen since 2018, increasing from an
"excellent" rating of 39% in 2018 to 42% in 2020, and "Fair" and "Poor" ratings decreased from
12% in 2018 down to 9% in 2020. An impressive 92% give "excellent" or "good" ratings to
Cambridge as "a place to live," and 89% give "excellent" or "good" ratings to Cambridge as "a
safe place to live." Moving forward, we will closely monitor areas that saw decreases in the
"excellent" ratings, such as: economic development (-12), a place to raise a child (-8), a place
welcoming to all races and cultures (-7) ability to have a positive impact on the community (-7),
ability to participate in government (-6), and environmental planning and policy (-6).
This year's survey also found that the percentage of residents who have ridden a bike more than
26 times (48%) has gone up 4 points since 2018, and those visiting a park more than 26 times
(48%) has gone up 2 points since 2018. The percentage of residents who say they have "never"
attended a City Council meeting (57%) has dropped 7 points since 2018.
The number of people who have visited the City's website more than 26 times (15%) has tripled
from 2018. The share of residents who say they have "never" visited the website (10%) is down
17 points since 2018. The primary method of conducting business with the City is now through
the website (47%), and in-person interactions are down 15 points, dropping from 32% in 2018 to
just 17% in 2020.
The survey was conducted September 9 -September 13, 2020. The statistically valid random
telephone survey of residents has been conducted every two years since 2000 and was led by
Polity Research Consulting. A web version supplemented this year's survey, with 2,551
individual respondents completing the survey. The survey responses provide a snapshot of
public sentiment towards various issues and public services in the City. Some variation in the
results from survey to survey is expected. In reviewing the survey results, it is important to pay
attention to any emerging and long-term trends.
Packet Pg. 3

1

I hope you will look closely at the report by Polity Research Consulting to view all of the
changes in the 2020 survey. Also enclosed is a separate compilation of aggregated results for
various responses and corresponding survey results since 2000. Overall, for the 42 questions in
this survey with historical data, 77% of the 2020 aggregated responses (32 questions) are above
the historical average for each of the questions (see attached worksheet).
I expect to work closely with City departments to further analyze the results to incorporate
relevant insights into priorities and future work plans, and the overall budget process. I
anticipate that the survey results will be a valuable tool for the Council and the public to
understand community issues. I welcome a more detailed exploration of the survey results with
the Council. I am happy to ask a representative from Polity Research Consulting to attend a
committee meeting.

Packet Pg. 16

2020 Resident Opinion Survey
Prepared for The City of Cambridge, MA
October 15, 2020
Polity Research Consulting LLC

Packet Pg. 17

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

1.b

1.b

Polity Research Consulting conducted a random telephone survey among 400 adult residents of
the City of Cambridge, Massachusetts between September 9th and September 13th, 2020. The
sample was constructed to represent the adult population of the city—and was comprised of both
landline (30%) and cell-phone (70%) households. Every household in the city had an equal chance
of being selected in the sample. The margin of error on the full, 400-member sample is ±4.90% at
the mid-range of the 95% confidence interval. That is, when conducting 100 such surveys, 95 of
them will yield results that fall—at worst—4.9 points on either side of a given percentage. When
looking at smaller segments of the sample, the margins of error will increase.

E XECUTIVE S UMMARY O F K EY F INDINGS
All in all, the results to this survey show that, while evaluations of Cambridge city services and
city characteristics have suffered during the COVID-19 pandemic, core attributes have either held
steady or improved. Moreover, the City's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic is widely regarded
as positive by more than four in five residents. Considering the current health, political and social
climate, these results suggest that the City is generally continuing to do well during a very difficult
period.
Here is a summary of the key findings:
• Affordable housing is still the number one issue facing residents (30%)—and the top issue
residents want the city to address. COVID-19 and education are also high on the issues list;
• Overall city performance is up slightly since 2018—with fully two-thirds (66%) giving the city
either "excellent" (16%) or "good" (50%) ratings. In 2018, 63% gave the city positive ratings on
this measure;
• On a range of city characteristics, "excellent" ratings dropped on several since 2018. The biggest
drops occurred on: economic development (-12), a place to raise a child (-8), a place welcoming
to all races and cultures (-7) ability to have a positive impact on the community (-7), ability to
participate in government (-6), environmental planning and policy (-6). "Excellent" ratings
increased the most since 2018 on: a safe place to live (+7), quality of life (+3), ability to get around
town by car (+3);
• The percentage of residents who have ridden a bike more than 26 times has gone up 4 points
since 2018, while library utilization at that level has dropped 4 points. Those visiting a park more

2
Packet Pg. 18

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

M ETHODOLOGY

1.b

• Tellingly, the number of people who have visited the City's website more than 26 times has
tripled—from 5% in 2018 to 15% today. Also, the share of residents who say they have "never"
visited the website is down 17 points since 2018;
* Similarly, the primary method of conducting business with the City is now through the website
(47%—up from 31% in 2018). In-person interactions are down 15 points—going from 32% in
2018 to just 17% today;
• On a range of City services, several suffered drops in "excellent" ratings from 2018. The biggest
drops were: fire department services (-16), schools and education (-15), and police department
services (-10). The biggest increases in "excellent" ratings were: street cleaning and maintenance
(+9) and public information (+3);
• On satisfaction with city government interactions, 24% of residents place themselves on the most
positive scale position ("5", "totally satisfied"). This is the exact same reading we got in both 2018
and 2016. Interestingly, the next most satisfied scale position ("4") went up 5 points since 2018;
• Fully 81% of residents give the City either "excellent" (38%) or "good" (43%) ratings on its
overall handling the COVID-19 pandemic. On specific services, residents assign the best marks to
trash collection and recycling (37% "excellent"), public information services (30%), Public Health
services (27%), online/virtual City services (26%) and (despite the overall ratings given) Public
Safety services (Police and Fire) (21%);
• Almost one-third of our respondents (32%) say someone in their household lost employment
income since the mid-March "lockdown";
• Almost three-quarters of our sample (73%) say they follow public health updates and
recommendations on COVID-19 "a lot". Another 19% follow these "some" of the time;
• State government (38%) is the most trusted source of information on COVID-19, followed by
the City of Cambridge at 24%. The Federal government lags far behind both at just 4%. About
one-quarter (26%) volunteer that they trust the city and state governments equally, while 5%
distrust all levels of government on this score;
• Far fewer residents agree with a statement that were unable to conduct business with the city
during regular business hours. In 2018, 43% agreed with the statement—today that number is just
32%.

What follows is a question-by-question analysis of the full survey results.

3
Packet Pg. 19

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

than 26 times has gone up 2 points since 2018. The percentage who say they have "never" attended
a City Council meeting has dropped 7 points since 2018.

1.b

To start this year’s survey, we asked respondents to tell us what they view as the single most
important issue facing the City of Cambridge—the one that affects them and their families the
most. As the chart shows, affordable housing tops the list (as it has for the past several surveys),
followed by issues surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic, education and schools, jobs and the
economy, and climate change issues. Next on the list are infrastructure and transportations issues
and race relations.

4
Packet Pg. 20

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

M OST I MPORTANT I SSUES F ACING C AMBRIDGE

1.b

As the chart shows, two-thirds of our sample (66%) now give the city either “excellent” or
“good” marks on overall performance of city government in Cambridge—up 3 points from the
2018 reading. This year, 16% assign “excellent” ratings to overall performance—the same score
we saw in 2018. Moreover, 50% give the city “good” marks—up three points since 2018.

Demographically, the highest “excellent” performance ratings come from: Cambridgeport
(29%), North Cambridge (21%) and West Cambridge (20%); residents over the age of 56 (21%);
the highest-income earners (24%); and homeowners (22%).

5
Packet Pg. 21

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

C ITY P ERFORMANCE A ND S ATISFACTION R ATINGS

1.b

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

Similarly, as the chart shows, 60% of residents place themselves on scale positions representing
“satisfaction” with their city government interactions. We also found that 24% of residents place
themselves on the most positive scale position ("5", "totally satisfied")—the exact same reading
we got in both 2018 and 2016. The next most satisfied scale position ("4") went up 5 points
since 2018.

6
Packet Pg. 22

1.b

C ITY A TTRIBUTE R ATINGS

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

Next, respondents were asked to rate a range of city attributes. Perceptions of the quality of life
in Cambridge have risen since 2018—going from an “excellent” rating of 39% to 42% today
“Fair” and “Poor” ratings have gone from a total of 12% down to 9%. Excellent ratings for
quality of neighborhood have also gone up—although overall positive ratings have remained
roughly stable from 2018. Fully 92% give “excellent” or “good” ratings to Cambridge as “a
place to live”—up by one point since 2018. Perceptions of Cambridge as an “excellent” or
“good” place to retire have gone up 6 points since 2018, while “excellent” ratings for safety in
the city have gone up a full 7 points. “Excellent” ratings for raising a child in the city have
dropped from 41% in 2018 to 33% today.

7
Packet Pg. 23

1.b

Next, respondents were asked to rate a series of city characteristics in Cambridge. As the composite
chart indicates, ‘ability to get around town on foot’ receives the highest “excellent” rating (44%),
while ‘access to affordable housing’ get the lowest “excellent rating (1%). While ‘a place
welcoming to all races and cultures’ finishes second on the lost, it should be noted that this
measured suffered a 7-point drop in “excellent” ratings from 2018. “Excellent” ratings on ‘a sense
of community’ also fell—going from 21% in 2018 to 18% today. Troubling drops also occurred
on ‘economic development’ (“excellent” ratings down 12 points), ‘ability to have positive impact
on the community’ (“excellent” ratings down 7 points), and ‘ability to participate in government’
(“excellent” ratings down 6 points). Clearly, most of these drops were due in part to the impact of
COVID-19 on the community.

8
Packet Pg. 24

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

R ATINGS O F C ITY C HARACTERISTICS

1.b

Respondents were also asked to tell us how many times they had participated in a range of activities
around the city. As the chart shows, the percentage of residents who have ridden a bike more than
26 times stands at 34%—up 4 points since 2018, while library utilization at that level has dropped
4 points (now at 20%). Those visiting a park more than 26 times is now at 48%— up 2 points since
2018. The percentage who say they have "never" attended a City Council meeting has dropped 7
points since 2018—now at 57%. And, the number of people who have visited the City's website
more than 26 times has tripled—from 5% in 2018 to 15% today. Also, the share of residents who
say they have "never" visited the website is down 17 points since 2018 (now at just10%).

9
Packet Pg. 25

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

F REQUENCY O F A CTIVITIES

1.b

Respondents were also asked to tell us, their primary method of conducting business with the City.
As the chart shows, the city’s website is now the top method used by residents—at 47%, up from
31% in 2018. In-person interactions are down 15 points—going from 32% in 2018 to just 17%
today. Again, this is at least partly due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

10
Packet Pg. 26

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

P RIMARY M ETHOD O F C ONDUCTING B USINESS

1.b

Respondents were also asked to rate a range of City services on a scale of “excellent” to “poor”.
Several services suffered drops in "excellent" ratings from 2018. The biggest drops were: fire
department services (-16), schools and education (-15), and police department services (-10). The
biggest increases in "excellent" ratings were: street cleaning and maintenance (+9) and public
information (+3). The chart below shows that ‘library services’ top the list this year with the
highest percentage of “excellent” ratings (53%), followed by ‘city parks and maintenance’ (37%)
and (despite the large drop since 2018) fire department services (36%).

11
Packet Pg. 27

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

R ATINGS O F S PECIFIC C ITY S ERVICES

1.b

The 2020 Resident Survey contained several new questions dealing with the COVID-19 pandemic.
First, we discovered that nearly one-third of our sample (32%) report some loss of employment in
their household since the COVID-19 ‘lockdown’ began in mid-March.

Demographically, reported job loss was highest in: West Cambridge, The Port and Porter Square.
Reported job loss was twice as high as the norm (64%) among Hispanic residents and also
significantly higher among African-American residents (45%).

12
Packet Pg. 28

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

T HE C ITY A ND T HE COVID-19 P ANDEMIC

1.b

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

As the chart indicates, more than four in five residents (81%) of residents give the city either
"excellent" (38%) or "good" (43%) ratings on its overall handling the COVID-19 pandemic. Just
a total of 15% give the city negative marks (12% “fair”, 3% “poor”).

13
Packet Pg. 29

1.b

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

On specific service performance during the pandemic, residents assign the best marks to trash
collection and recycling (37% "excellent"), public information services (30%), Public Health
services (27%), online/virtual City services (26%) and (despite the overall ratings given) Public
Safety services (Police and Fire) (21%).

14
Packet Pg. 30

1.b

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

As the following chart shows, almost three-quarters of our sample (73%) say they follow public
health updates and recommendations on COVID-19 "a lot". Another 19% follow these "some" of
the time. Just a total of 5% follow the updates and recommendations to a lesser degree.

15
Packet Pg. 31

1.b

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

The next chart indicates that state government (38%) is the most trusted source of information on
COVID-19, followed by the City of Cambridge at 24%. The Federal government lags far behind
both at just 4%. About one-quarter (26%) volunteer that they trust the city and state governments
equally, while 5% distrust all levels of government on this score.

16
Packet Pg. 32

1.b

This year, we found that far fewer residents agree with a statement that were “unable to conduct
business with the city during regular business hours”. In 2018, 43% agreed with the statement—
today that number is just 32%. This is most likely partly due to the expanded availability and use
of online city resources during the COVID-19 pandemic.

17
Packet Pg. 33

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

E ASE O F C ONDUCTING B USINESS W ITH T HE C ITY

1.b

As we saw with the “most important problem” question at the top of the survey, ‘affordable
housing’ is again cited as the top issue that city government should focus on. As the chart shows,
‘infrastructure’ comes in at a distant second—followed by issues related to the COVID-19
pandemic, ‘education and schools”, “economy and jobs”, “bike issues” and “climate change”. For
an issue like infrastructure to appear so near the top of the priorities list is an indication of the real
emergence of this concern. Specific references to this and all other issues on the list can be found
in the verbatim file of responses.

18
Packet Pg. 34

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

R ECOMMENDED I SSUE F OCUS

Attachment: 2020_Resident_Survey_Report_010421 (CMA 2021 #2 : 2020 Resident Telephone Survey)

1.b

Now, I’d like to read you one final list dealing with various city services provided by Cambridge.

1.c

1.c

Police Department Services

73%

Packet Pg. 92

1.1

City of Cambridge
COF 2021 #5
IN CITY COUNCIL
January 25, 2021

Packet Pg. 93

September 2020

Cambridge Resident Survey

Attachment: Polity_Cambridge_Resident_Survey_1_24_21 (COF 2021 #5 : Presentation for

1.1.a

Packet Pg. 94

Key Findings
• Core measures (performance of city
government, satisfaction with city government
interactions) have improved or remained steady;
• Affordable housing is still the top problem, with
COVID‐19 now second on the list;
• More than four in five residents (81%) assign
positive marks for the city’s handling of the
pandemic

Attachment: Polity_Cambridge_Resident_Survey_1_24_21 (COF 2021 #5 : Presentation for

1.1.a

Attachment: Polity_Cambridge_Resident_Survey_1_24_21 (COF 2021 #5 : Presentation for

1.1.a

Packet Pg. 132

Q1

Q1O
10 PUBLIC SCHOOLS.
THE SINGLE BIGGEST ISSUE CAMBRIDGE IS FACING IS THE
1 COVID‐19 PANDEMIC.
THE CORONA‐VIRUS RESPONSE WAS TERRIBLE, IT SHOULD'VE
1 BEEN HANDLED BETTER.
THE ECONOMY AND THE FACT THAT THINGS ARE NOT OPEN.
1
3 ENDING RACISM IS MOST IMPORTANT ISSUE.
I FEEL EDUCATION IS THE MOST IMPORTANT THING RIGHT
NOW, HIGH SCHOOL EDUCATION FIRST NEEDS TO BE
10 ADDRESSED THOUGH.
THE ISSUE THAT AFFECTS US THE MOST IS THE ANARCHY THAT
16 IS APPARENT IN MANY PARTS OF THE COUNTRY.
THE PRICES OF HOUSING IS OUTRAGEOUS, IT NEEDS TO
9 BROUGHT BACK DOWN.
I FEEL THAT THE SINGLE MOST IMPORTANT ISSUE FACING
CAMBRIDGE IS RACIAL ISSUES. ALTHOUGH I AM A PRIVILEGED
WHITE MALE, I TRULY RESPECT THE BLACK LIVES MATTER
3 MOVEMENT.
I THINK THE BIGGEST ISSUE IS WILL THE COUNTRY CONTINUE
16 AS A DEMOCRACY OR NOT.
10 EDUCATION.
THE BIGGEST ISSUE IS LETTING THE KIDS BACK TO SCHOOL
10 ASAP.
THE COST OF HOUSING IS RIDICULOUS AND NEEDS TO BE
9 ADDRESSED.
15 THERE IS NO INFRASTRUCTURE IN CAMBRIDGE.
9 THE HOUSING CRISIS.
MORE AFFORDABLE HOUSING SHOULD BE AVAILABLE HERE.
9
10 SCHOOLS.
14 THE HEALTHCARE SYSTEM.
99 I HAVE NO OPINION ON THIS MATTER AT THIS TIME.
THE MOST IMPORTANT ISSUE THAT CAMBRIDGE IS FACING IS
9 HOUSING.
9 HOUSING IS A VERY SERIOUS.

4

I THINK THE MOST IMPORTANT ISSUE IS THE POLICE
GUIDANCE. IN MY OPINION, THE POLICE SHOULD BE
RETRAINED AND GIVEN MORE SENSITIVITY TRAINING INSTEAD
OF BULLYING THE PEOPLE. I ALSO THINK THE FACT THAT THE
PUBLIC PAYS THEIR SALARY SHOULD BE TOP PRIORITY WHEN

THE ECONOMY IN CAMBRIDGE NEEDS SOME SERIOUS HELP.
11
98 SAFETY GETTING FOOD IN PUBLIC.
9 RENT PRICES ARE WAY TOO MUCH MONEY.

Attachment: Copy of Cambridge Verbatims (COF 2021 #5 : Presentation for Roundtable/Working Group City Council Meeting)

1.1.b

Packet Pg. 133

I THINK AFFORDABLE HOUSING IS IMPORTANT ISSUE AT THIS
9 TIME.
HOUSING IS THE SINGLE BIGGEST ISSUE IN MY POINT OF VIEW
9 IN CAMBRIDGE.
